item.title: How people are learning and teaching code: UX research snippets
item.dc:creator: Donna Choi
item.content:encoded:
UX research snippets: How people are learning and teachingÂ code

ğŸ™‹ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸ Hello! Here at Stack Overflow, we recently started sharing UX research findings with our Meta community to provide visibility into one of the inputs we use to make product decisions. You can see all past UX research updates here, as well as data science updates from my colleague, Julia Silge. Iâ€™m cross-posting these findings to my personalÂ blog.

Today, Iâ€™ll be talking about findings from user research we conducted about how people are learning to code and teaching others how toÂ code.

Research background

This research was motivated by questions of how Stack Overflow may better serve people new to programming. More specifically:

  1. What motivates new developers to learn to code, and how are they learning? What tools or communities are they using, and what do their workflows lookÂ like?
  2. How are code teachers teaching people to code? Any best practices, what resources do they share with their students, and what do their workflows lookÂ like?

We conducted interviews with people sourced from our social networks and the community. Participants included people with less than 3 years of programming experience, a college Python instructor, Stack Overflow moderators and answerers, and leaders of various technology communities. Out of respect for peopleâ€™s privacy, any quotes Iâ€™ve included here have been combined or paraphrased.

What motivates new developers to learn to code, and how are they learning?

The new coders I spoke to were driven to learn code so they could make career changes. They are self-taught and used a wide range of resources to learn, including online courses, YouTube videos, blogs, demos, and Twitter. They initiated their learning process via online courses (discovered via Google), and organically amassed resources overÂ time.

â€œI found resources by googling â€œlearning to code python.â€ One of the resources I found showed me an online course. Then I found out about Code Academy. Iâ€™ve progressed from online courses to books to YouTube channels. The more confident I became, I [learned] that following tech people on Twitter is a great way to figure out how to get new resources.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠNew coder, 3 years experience
â€œIâ€™m learning because I want to leave clinical medicine and go into research/policy analysis. I started using Datacamp last spring to learn R.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠNew coder, 1 year experience

New coders describe being overwhelmed at the beginning of their learning processâ€Šâ€”â€Ševerything from vocabulary to the research process was new. This insight was strongly reflected in the experiences of those teaching code, who described the need to scaffold information for their students and to teach them how to gather information properly.

â€œI take 5 min to find something, evaluate 30 pages, looked at 5, spend 1â€“2 min on each, and navigated to one. Whatever time it takes me to deal with it, itâ€™ll take a novice 10x. If I have to go through 30 pages of search results then what do you expect of a novice? It takes learning to put natural language vocab to a coding question; those are words you donâ€™t have yet.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠCollege instructor
â€œSometimes you donâ€™t even know what to search for. Sometimes copy and pasting an error helps, other times you come up with your own keyword search. When youâ€™re learning itâ€™s hard to know what to doâ€¦ What people consider normal tech language can be super overwhelming. [On SO sometimes people say] â€˜donâ€™t ask questions you havenâ€™t tried to find an answer forâ€™. It would be nice if they could elaborate on ways to search the site.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠNew coder, 1 year experience

What motivates people to teach and lead code communities, and how do theyÂ teach?

Those teaching others to code are cautious about referring students to Stack Overflow. They described good teachers as being skilled in deconstructing student questions and scaffolding information.

â€œCan you scaffold them to get there when teaching? You canâ€™t just throw them the whole thing. Iâ€™m thinking about the problem differently than how a learner is learning about the problem. Can I try to understand the learners POV and how to break it down? What scaffolding will they need?â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠLeader in technology community
â€œStudents need a safe space to ask questions. A question from a novice is not just about technical clarification. A noviceâ€™s mental model is what has to be correctedâ€¦ I usually caution against them using SO because the discussions there are working at a higher level than they need to be worrying about.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠCollege instructor

People are incentivized to donate their time to Stack Overflow, open source communities, and teaching for philanthropic and practical reasons: to develop their careers, receive professional recognition, and to give back to communities that benefited them.

â€œ[I got involved in open source] because I wanted to engage in activities that signaled my professional credibility.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠLeader in technology community
â€œSome people have the time capacity and [like the] philanthropic aspects. Others will require more incentive. I usually [answer questions] to help out and as a resume builder.â€â€Šâ€”â€ŠStack OverflowÂ answerer

Next steps

This research is being used to help us to continue improving the guidance we provide to question askers. Itâ€™s also informing initiatives outside of the Community product team. If youâ€™d like to participate in future user research sessions, you can join the research email list via your email settings.

ğŸ¤˜Thanks for reading! Whatâ€™s been your experience learning to code or teaching others to code? What do you wish you knew when you started to program or learn a new technology?

item.title: Remote design sprinting at Stack Overflow
item.dc:creator: Courtny Cotten
item.content:encoded:
My hobby is coaching. I spend my evenings coaching youth and high school athletes in Track & Field & CrossÂ Country.

I approach much of my design thinking in a similar manner as my coaching; prescribe appropriate frameworks to elicit a response, always look for opportunities of improvement, and be ready to adapt the toolkit to novel problems.

At Stack Overflow, I was tapped to lead our product team using design sprints to explore broad new concepts. We are specifically interested in helping developers grow by providing new ways for them to participate and connect on our platform.

In this lengthy article, I will talk about how we used design techniques to explore problems and test solutions quickly, and how I adapted a framework to creatively answer critical business questions facing ourÂ team.

The Challenge

Our team is remote. We have several different product segments and a very passionate and opinionated meta community. We also have many different stakeholders with strong opinions of how we can expand our services to developers and help them find better careers. Our product is tested, proven, and well known. So why upset thatÂ balance?

Our product team wanted to swing for the fences. We had tried several different design techniques in the past to move projects along ~ from whole product games to vision quests. While these proved useful to generate a lot of ideas rapidly, they did not meet our needs when it came to validating key ideas or aligning the team on solutions.

Using Googleâ€™s Design Sprint Kit as a backbone, we adapted their workflows to our unique remote circumstances.

Meetings that are supposed to be in person, now had to be remote. This required using tools in different ways.

Tools we used: Trello, Figma, Google Documents, Hangouts, Respondent Screenflow, Github Pages,Â Stacks

We are also spread across the U.S. and all have different workingÂ hours.

Locations & Time Zones: Des (California), Max (New York City), Courtny (Indiana), Piper (Ohio), Kirti (New York City), Elaine (New YorkÂ City)

The SprintÂ Plan

We had five days to work on our design sprint. This was an intentional and necessary time box. We wanted our teamâ€™s full attention and efforts focused to achieve the best outcome, while delivering maximumÂ value.

Time is precious, so we were stingy during the sprint. We were even more aggressive and squished down the traditional 6 hour sessions into a 4 hour time block each day. We found that being remote and async allowed individuals to work individually within the rest of their workday as they deemedÂ fit.

The initial plan consisted of 5 days. Each day was broken down into aÂ â€œthemeâ€.

Our schedule roughly looked likeÂ this:

  • Day 1: Create a shared understanding
  • Day 2: Brainstorm & sketch all theÂ thingz
  • Day 3: Decide what toÂ build
  • Day 4: Build the damnÂ thing
  • Day 5: Test it and see what peopleÂ think

There are also different roles we filled during the sprint. Itâ€™s key to have a Sprint Lead, Decider, and a Technical expert. It was a bonus that we were able to have Marketing, Design, and User Research also involved.

  • Sprint Lead: The sprint lead facilitates and runs all of the sessions. The lead prepares all content, guides the team through exercises, and keeps everything on track and organized. In our situation, I served as the sprintÂ lead.
  • Decider: The decider role is very important. This person makes the final decisions on product direction and ideas. They need to listen to their team and be able to build consensus among team members. Aligning folks on shared vision is their goal during the sprint. We had one of our Talent Product Manager, Desiree Darilek serve as the decider during theÂ sprint.
  • Tech Expert(s): These people advise on technical matters, but also assist with building the final prototype. They are key members of all design activities. Max Horstmann & Kirti Thorat, developers on the Talent product served in thisÂ role.
  • Marketing Expert(s): Provided guidance on product positioning. Elaine Wang our Product Marketing Manager filled thisÂ spot.
  • Design Expert(s): Gave guidance on user experience considerations, as well as helped with final designs for the prototype. Piper Lawson and I provided supportÂ here.
  • User Research: Our resident research specialist, Kristina Lustig assisted us with all the planning for our user research sessions and facilitated the discussions with users on the final testingÂ day.
The ideal team here is no more than 6â€“8 people. Too many people can stagnate decisions. The sprintâ€™s goal is to reach decisions quickly, prototype those decisions, and testÂ them.

Day 1: Shared Understanding

Before we started our sprint, we needed to lay down ground rules for all involved and what the expectations were. We also needed to pick the brains of the subject matter experts we have in our company, and reflect on past research and activities.

Set a long-term goal

â€œWhy are we doing this project? Where do we want to be in 1 month, 6 months, or a year fromÂ now?â€

We spent time as a team discussing and understanding each otherâ€™s perspectives. Itâ€™s very important for each person to actively listen to one another. We designated a note taker so we could reflect on the discussion.

Hereâ€™s anÂ example:

Our Ideal outcomeâ€Šâ€”â€Ša strong direction for our product. How do we â€œ10Xâ€ our offering to developers?
Problemâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCan we provide more value back to our developers when it comes to engaging with companies, jobs, each other? Can developers enrich their careers and opportunities by using Stack Overflow? Will Stack Overflow be able to deliver on thatÂ vision?

Sprint questions

Once our team had a shared understanding of each individuals perspectives, and we aligned on ideals and problems, we moved into identifying what questions we wanted to answer during theÂ sprint.

Sprint questions are also a time to be honest as a team and identify what hurdles will be in your path as you try to innovate.

In our case, internal pressures and the desire to be conservative with our core product offering was identified as the biggest challenge to any new ideas we presented.

The core questions your team should beÂ asking:

â€¢ What questions do we need to answer in thisÂ sprint?
â€¢ To meet our long-term goal, what has to beÂ true?
â€¢ Imagine we travel into the future and our project failed. What could have causedÂ that?

Idea review

We had a lot of previous research, archived design sessions, and insights to reflect on. We also have had failed projects from the past, and we want to learn from those mistakes.

Leaning on this previous knowledge gave us a head start on our solution, as well as helped us make more educated assumptions.

We were able to identify common trends and themes reappearing across all of these different pieces we had. Retroactively reviewing these findings, design documents, and conversations sped up our process and allowed old ideas to be brought back into the spotlight.

Map your solutions

Once the team identified the goals and failures, it was time to start thinking about possible solutions.

For most people I find that they already have a solution pre-baked into their head. Itâ€™s usually attached to a specific feature, or core feature but it is rarely completely detailed. Much less an end-to-end story.

By providing your team with a structure you can begin to scaffold moreÂ detail.

Our team chose to take a â€œstory basedâ€ approach. Its a simple concept that most anyone can begin to break their solution downÂ with.

Whatâ€™s the beginning, middle, and end of your story that solves our long termÂ goal?

Each individual took some time to prepare a short story. Then we presented to one another. The design sprint facilitator pulled together common themes and highlighted particularly strong ideas. The team worked together to build the narrative.

Stakeholder Interviews

Speaking with stakeholders about this shared story was the nextÂ step.

This was less of a presentation of the teamâ€™s work, and more about our team asking questions that filled in the gaps of the story. These people helped our team identify pitfalls, reflect on old initiatives, and uncover additional opportunities.

When doing this session, here are a fewÂ tips.

Take the time to be opinionated about the product direction. Assume brand new features exist that help tell your story. As an example, you might ask an ads stakeholder: â€œIn what ways do you think companies would want to promote their content [we do not have this today]? Do we feel like this would be intrusive to the userâ€™s experience [meta may dislike it]? Why and why not?[help the Stackholder consider bothÂ sides]â€

Asking hypothetical questions allows you to temper new ideas rapidly with these key people, and also gets their minds working to address new (and sometimes potentially disruptive) ideas.

For our company, these are the team members and product areas we had represented:
â€¢ Puneet Mulchandani & Sean Baveâ€” TalentÂ strategy
â€¢ Noah Meiri & Yi Shanâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAds
â€¢ Joe Friendâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDAG context, whatâ€™s theÂ mindset
â€¢ JNatâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDev community, Cogro/Meta mindset
â€¢ Donna Choiâ€” Dev community, user motivations (Public Q&A, Teams,Â Jobs)

Homework: Product Teardowns

At the conclusion of the day, we broke down as individuals to work quietly. We asked each individual to find products and services that could serve as an inspiration for this design sprint. Each person was to prepare to share their homework on DayÂ 2.

Day 2: Brainstorming & Sketching

On day two the team members were focused on creating a design solution sketch by the end of the day. This is basically a visual representation of the core features that will bring our story outlined in Day 1 to life. Day 2 was composed of activities that helped focus the team on rapidly generating a lot of ideas and exploring them.

Review & RefineÂ Story

We started off the day reviewing the long term goal, sprint questions, solutions map, and all the expert interviews. Was there anything that we should change in our story based on those sessions?

Lightning Demos

For the lightning demos, we compiled a list of all the products and services people brought to show and tell. We had each individual give a 3-minute tour of the product or service, and highlight exactly what features are standout toÂ them.

For these lightning demos, each team member presented on Google Hangouts, while a note taker compiled all of the interesting features and concepts each personÂ covered.

Sketch

The sketching activities took up the majority of the day. Here we chose to focus on a couple of different sketch activities, although there are several methods for your team to try and use. We chose to use â€œHow Might Weâ€™sâ€, â€œCrazy 8'sâ€ and then move onto the Design Solution Sketches.

Beginning with How Might Weâ€™s allowed us to take the problems we would face and pose them as opportunities for design. This is a common design activity that guides people to believe the answer is out there, may or may not work, and reminds people that the sprint is about teamwork and riffing on otherâ€™s ideas. The team is working to create opportunities versus narrowing down solutions tooÂ early.

Our team came up with a couple of broad â€œHow Might Weâ€ statements, and then began providing their individual solutions forÂ each.

How Might We examples:

  • How might we curateÂ content?
  • How might we introduce new contentÂ types?
  • How might we guide developers careers?
  • How might we connect the developers and employers?

This activity spawned many ideas, but even more rich conversations and exploration about how we may execute. This was precisely what we were going for! Seeing everyoneâ€™s HMWâ€™s opened the field for discussion. We then started organizing each of the HMWâ€™s into broader category buckets so we could see some of the common ideas our teamÂ shared.

In fact, this exercise took so much time we did not get the chance to dive into Crazy 8â€™s sketching. This wasnâ€™t necessarily a bad thing. The Crazy 8â€™s exercise is in place to challenge team members to rapidly sketch 8 distinct ideas on paper. This wasnâ€™t mission critical since our team was aligning behind some of the shared ideas being presented during the HMW exercise.

One comment here as the facilitator is: donâ€™t shut down good, productive discussion. Our team was really on a roll creating and detailing some of the HMW themes. So I called an audible and let us go an hour longer on that segment to make sure we captured everyoneâ€™s thoughts and insights.

We ended the How Might We session by allowing each team member to vote on their favorite HMW cards on the Trello board. Each individual only got three votes, and with nearly 60+ different ideas this was difficult. However, it forced each individual to focus on the core story they wanted to tell and that they felt emphasized our goals as aÂ team.

We began to see alignment.

We then closed off the day creating our Solution Sketches. This activity focused on defining the key visuals of product ideas in action. The team members would create a sketch focused on the major keyframes that would need to exist for their solution to be brought to life. Once their sketches were completed, they emailed them to me where they were compiled into a single Figma document.

Some things to keep in mind while doing a solutionÂ sketch:

  • Make it self-explanatory. It needs to explain itself without you presenting it. If people canâ€™t understand it on itâ€™s own, then it probably wonâ€™t make sense when itâ€™s polishedÂ either.
  • Keep it anonymous. Donâ€™t put your name on the sketch. We want to evaluate ideasâ€Šâ€”â€ŠnotÂ people.
  • Ugly is fine. The sketch doesnâ€™t have to be fancy and polished. It just needs to have enough detail, be thoughtful, and complete.
  • Words matter. Donâ€™t use â€œtext will go hereâ€ headlines. Think about the copy you would use. Strong writing is an important productÂ element.
  • Give it a catchy title. The title helps us keep track of the different solutions. Itâ€™s also a way of drawing attention to your bigÂ idea.

Bonus: Lightning Research Interviews

We had the luxury of testing these solution sketches, and receive some early user reactions to them. This was a luxury because it provided some great high level feedback and insights moving into Day 3 where we decide on a final design to prototype. This was done completely remote and reminded me a lot of testing paper prototypes with users inÂ person.

Day 3:Â Deciding

Decision day is the most critical to the sprint. This is the day your team will decide on what to ultimately build and test in order to answer your sprint questions.

Before our team dug in, we spent time at the beginning of the day reviewing work to date. This was a good time to collect comments and feedback on the brainstorm and sketching activities you did previously so we could improve that process in theÂ future.

Heat Mapping the Design Solutions

Our first activity of the day was reviewing the design solutions each team member created. This review session was coupled with a heat mapping exercise and speed critiqueÂ session.

All of the sketches were placed into one Figma document that was shared with all team members. Team members design solutions were kept anonymous from one another. Each team member was asked to do the following heat mapping exercise:

  • Donâ€™t talk.
  • Look at a solutionÂ sketch.
  • Put dots besides parts that you like, commenting with a simpleÂ â€œ+1â€
  • If you really like an idea, put 2 or 3Â â€œ+1â€.
  • Comment on parts you reallyÂ like.
  • If you have a concern or question, comment on thatÂ part.
  • Move on to the next sketch, andÂ repeat.

Speed Critiquing the Design Solutions

Once the heat map was completed, we moved onto the speed critique.

The overall goal of this session was to create a record of promising ideas for the prototype. We didnâ€™t need to debate if they should be included, we just presented each idea. This was a purposefully focused time period (30 minutes) and it helped to have a dedicated note taker, allowing the sprint leader to narrate the solutions to theÂ team.

For each design solution we did the following:

  • Set a timer for threeÂ minutes.
  • The sprint lead narrated theÂ sketch.
  • The sprint lead called out standout ideas that have +1â€™s around aÂ theme.
  • The team noted any ideas the sprint leadÂ missed.
  • The note taker wrote down the standout ideas and gave each idea a simple name, such as â€œAnimated Videoâ€ or â€œOne-step Signupâ€.
  • Review concerns and suggestions that wereÂ noted.
  • The solution creator remained silent until the end. (â€œCreator, reveal your identity and tell us what we missed!â€)
  • The solution creator revealed any missed ideas that the team failed to spot, and answered any questions.
  • The user researcher shared the feedback provided by users during the lightning interviews
  • Move on to the next design solution, repeat.

Straw Poll

Once we finished critique, we moved into aligning concepts. This activity focuses on getting folks on the sameÂ page.

We reviewed our long term goal as well as sprint questions. We were looking to identify the big, risky ideas that would have potential.

Each team member was asked to write down their favorite ideas shown during the critique. This could be an entire solution, or pieces from different solutions stitched together.

Once everyone was done, we went around to each individual and revealed their choices and they explained theirÂ votes.

Ultimately, it is the Decider who determines what ideas the team will explore in the prototype. This is all based on input from the team, but the decider is there to solve any disputes and get the team aligned on the solutions to be explored.

Des (our Decider) helped us identify what we wanted to focus on as aÂ team:
â€¢ Introduce new content types for exploration
â€¢ Figure out how we can curate content forÂ users.
â€¢ Enhancements to companyÂ pages

Prototype Storyboard

Our team now had solid direction for the prototype. The task now became breaking these high level concepts down into executable steps. This is the time we began to figure out exactly what the prototype would lookÂ like.

Hereâ€™s what weÂ did:

  1. Decide who the â€œstoryboard artistâ€ will be. This is the person(s) responsible for writing, note taking, and sketching ideas the team comes up with. We used a combination of Google Document + Figma to assemble the storyboard and any accompanying sketches.
  2. Create up to 10 storyboard frames. You can always use less, but max it out at ten. This will help to figure out how a user will experience the prototype, while also keeping the scopeÂ tight.

Imagine an opening scene for the prototype. What would be the natural starting point for users? An example opening scene: â€œUser clicks through a new post on Hacker News titled Stack Overflow introduces new community featuresâ€.

It was important to keep the following inÂ mind:

  • Work with what we have. Resist inventing new ideas. Work with the ideas we have already come upÂ with.
  • Donâ€™t write copy together. Either use headlines from the sketches or defer copywriting until tomorrow.
  • Include just enough detail. The storyboard should include just enough detail that nobody asks â€œwhat happens next?â€ or â€œwhat goes here?â€, but donâ€™t get too specific. It doesnâ€™t need to be perfect today. We can decide this tomorrow.
  • The Decider decides. Ultimately the Decider makes all final decisions. If we reach an impasse, we defer to the Decider and moveÂ on.
  • When in doubt, take risks. The sprint is for testing risky ideas with huge payoffs. Skip the easy wins for bold bets. This isnâ€™t the time to be conservative.
  • Keep it to 15 minutes or less. This will ensure we donâ€™t overbuild and it will help us make sure we leave enough time for customers to think aloud and answer questions.

Day 4: Build the Prototype

Now the team moves onto the build phase. It is here that the designers and developers involved in the sprint work together to breathe life into the sketches and documents created by the team. Their efforts provide the tangible vision to test withÂ users.

We started off the morning with a quick check-in; assigning roles and breaking downÂ tasks.

Our team decided to build the prototype using our user interface library, Stacks and depended on Github Pages to serve the content. Using Github allowed the designers and developers to collaborate on the project as it was beingÂ built.

Day 5: UserÂ Testing

Day 5 is when our team placed our vision in front ofÂ users.

Our prototype was ready and publicly accessible.

We were very interested in seeing their reactions to the project we had completed. The insights we gained from these sessions would inform the net big steps for ourÂ product.

Given the developer focus of Stack Overflow, we recruited seven developers of varying experience levels and familiarity with Stack Overflow to test with. Kristina Lustig ran our research sessions and provided a script to walk each of our usersÂ through.

Sprint team members were encouraged to sit in on the sessions, and were allowed to hear the userâ€™s feedback and see the reactions to the prototype.

Wrapping it all up:Â Findings

Following the research sessions, our team walked away with several findings that we could use. While we werenâ€™t provided a definitive strategy, we did spot major recurring themes that will inform our product trajectory.

As the sprint lead, it was my responsibility to wrap up insights from the research into a niceÂ package.

Closing

Leading a design sprint is intense. It requires a lot of preparation and active participation by everyone in theÂ sprint.

This can lead to exhaustion. Providing adequate breaks between sessions was important. Each day we got better at monitoring when to take a break, let the mind rest, and come back fueled up and ready to tackle the next batch ofÂ work.

Donâ€™t be afraid to take the traditional design sprint model and tweak it to your teams needs. Adapting the processes with some handy collaboration tools helped us bridge the physical-digital divide.

I am optimistic about Stack Overflow using this model more in our product development process.

It has certainly been a beneficial experience for our product team, and it was fun to go outside the box and thinkÂ big!

item.title: Stack Overflow Email Management: A UX Case Study
item.dc:creator: Donna Choi
item.content:encoded:
Stack Overflow email management: a UX caseÂ study

If you have an email account, youâ€™ve probably received a product email at some point. Chances are that your experience fell into one of theseÂ buckets:

  1. The email was helpful and relevant. Managing your emails was deadÂ simple.
  2. The email wasnâ€™t really helpful and only sort of relevant. It was mostly easy to opt-in or out of emails, but some settings were vague or hidden behind a loginÂ wall.
  3. The email was irrelevant, even misleading. It was difficult to opt-out; in fact, youâ€™re still receiving emails about this product after hitting â€œunsubscribe from allâ€ countless times.

Stack Overflowâ€™s email experience has hovered around #2â€Šâ€”â€Šthe emails we sent were mostly relevant, but management features were scattered and neglected in dark, dusty corners of the product. As we started to send more emails, there was a risk that weâ€™d slide into #3 unless we made some major improvements.

Our team set out to fix this experience, and hereâ€™s my take on ourÂ process.

This is the second in a two-part series about how we overhauled Stack Overflowâ€™s email management UX.

A quick history of email at StackÂ Overflow

Up until a year ago, Stack Overflow didnâ€™t send much email. There were a few emails sent to highly active Q&A users, plus emails for basic things like resetting your password or verifying your email address. The assumption was that users didnâ€™t want or need emails from us. If they wanted to hear from us, they could visit theÂ site.

This assumption was true for some usersâ€Šâ€”â€Šparticularly highly active Q&A users, who are already visiting the site regularly to moderate or participate in question threads. However, this is a small, expert slice of users. The majority of users visit irregularly to get answers, find a job, or learn about an interesting topicâ€Šâ€”â€Šand might miss content that would otherwise be interesting or beneficial toÂ them.

In fact, as we dug into metrics and user feedback, we found that users responded pretty positively to (relevant) email. Our assumptions about email started to shift and broaden, and we began lining up more email projects across theÂ product.

As more emails were sent, experience problemsâ€Šâ€”â€Šparticularly around email managementâ€Šâ€”â€Šbecame increasingly apparent. To understand these problems, letâ€™s back up and talk about the structure of Stack Overflow.

Stack Overflow is a product for developers. Itâ€™s composed of our flagship Q&A feature, Jobs (a job board for programming & programming-related jobs), a business entity, and Stack Exchange (a network of 150+ community sites on topics ranging from web security to cooking).

The product serves over 5 million users with varied tasks including (but not limitedÂ to):

  1. Answering someone elseâ€™s programming question
  2. Finding an answer to a cookingÂ question
  3. Finding aÂ job
  4. Building a new community around a topic like Pastafarianism.

Depending on the tasks and sites that a user engaged with, theyâ€™d need to visit three or more pages on disparate sites to manage their emails. Some of these pages were behind a login wall, and none were mobile-friendly. It was hard for users to know what they were subscribed to (or unsubscribed from). Some settings were synced across all sites, and others wereÂ not.

There were also major infrastructure problems that made improvements to our email sending and managing system costly to implement and difficult to measure, such as poor tracking, limited A/B testing capabilities, and a fragile deployment system.

Defining goals

The UX goal was simple: create an honest, clear, and easy-to-use email management system for users regardless of:

  • What tasks they were completing;
  • What sites they wereÂ using;
  • Whether they were logged in or not;Â and
  • What device they wereÂ using.

Side note: implementing a more robust email sending & tracking system was a significant part of this project, but this case study will focus on the above UX goalÂ only.

Conducting preliminary research

We started with an audit of our existing emails: what they said, where they came from, what conditions triggered them, and how they were grouped. This helped us broadly understand use cases and problemÂ areas.

We then conducted an analysis of email management solutions on otherÂ sites.

The goal was to learn from standards and insights already gained by other companies with similar needs. When analyzing these experiences, we asked questions like:

  • What do the best experiences have inÂ common?
  • What experiences reflect or contradict our principles?
  • What are the paths per use case (eg. logged in vs. logged out), device, and task? How, if at all, do theyÂ differ?

We then cobbled together this research, existing data, and past user feedback in order to identify and prioritize painÂ points.

Defining painÂ points

Pain Point #1: Managing emails on your phone was really hard. Users attempting to manage their email settings from their phones were simply sent to the desktop site, where they were expected to pinch and zoom in order to changeâ€Šâ€”â€Šor even seeâ€Šâ€”â€Štheir email settings. This presented usability and accessibility problems for a significant subset of users, since our data indicated that a large slice of email engagement occurred onÂ mobile.

This one might seem obvious in a mobile first world, but Stack Overflow has historically centered around Q&A, where users are writing code, reading and writing content, and testing code. These tasks overwhelmingly take place on desktop computers. The introduction of email grew mobile trafficâ€Šâ€”â€Šand consequently, led to more mobile investment.

Pain Point #2: You needed to login to manage or unsubscribe from some emails. If attempting to manage email settings while logged-outâ€Šâ€”â€Šperhaps while using a work computer or phoneâ€Šâ€”â€Šusers were sometimes blocked by a loginÂ wall.

Pain Point #3: Email settings were confusing and inconsistent across sites. In some cases, users needed to visit three or more pages on different domains to manage their emails. Some settings were synced across all 150+ sites, while others were site-specificâ€Šâ€”â€Šand it was hard to know one from theÂ other.

Pain Point #4: Email groupsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand which address they sent toâ€Šâ€”â€Šwere confusing. For example, users opted-in to the bucket pictured below were eligible to receive emails like beta feature invites, online event reminders, and notifications about their reputation milestonesâ€Šâ€”â€Šsomething that wasnâ€™t immediately clear. In some cases, those emails send to a different address than the one displayed on thisÂ page.

Designing and testing theÂ solution

We went through several design iterations before arriving at the solution. Each design iteration surfaced risks and open questions, which we explored through hallway and usability testing. Hereâ€™s our solution.

A touch-friendly mobile design. This addresses the difficulty of managing emails on mobile. A reusable toggle UI, which is both touch and desktop-friendly, can reduce implementation cost for future cross-device projects.

One-click unsubscribe and management for all users and emails. Even if youâ€™re logged out, you can control all of your emailsÂ easily.

Clear, consistent design across all network sites. This reduces the cognitive load of processing different design patterns when completing similar, or identical tasks. Multi-site vs. site-specific email settings are clearly organized and communicated to theÂ user.

Emails grouped based on common characteristics. We remapped emails and added new groups like Research and Tips & Reminders. Succinct, scannable copy and design makes it clear what you are subscribing and unsubscribing from.

Takeaways

Email management is one factor in our experiences with product emails. There are still plenty of improvements to make as we scale up email effortsâ€Šâ€”â€Šfor example, itâ€™s not only important that management is useful and easy, but that the emails themselves are those things and moreâ€Šâ€”â€Šrelevant, timely, and respectful. This also brings up questions about other communication channels that might be helpful to users, like in-product or mobile notifications.

Thanks for reading! To learn more about Stack Overflowâ€™s email settings project, check out my colleague Ted Goasâ€™s blog post, Designing a Better Email Preference Center. If you have your own stories about email, Iâ€™d love to hear. Please leave a comment or email me at donnachoi30@gmail.com.

item.title: Designing a Better Email Preference Center
item.dc:creator: Ted Goas
item.content:encoded:
Lessons and insights from redesigning Stack Overflowâ€™s email preferences.

Hi. Iâ€™m Ted and Iâ€™m on the Product Design team at Stack Overflow, a place where developers can get answers to their programming questions, find a job, and build communities around similar interests. Like many other websites, Stack Overflow sends email. Earlier this year, we set out to explore how we could improve our email experience. Weâ€™d love to share what we learned in theÂ process.

This is the first in a two part series about how weâ€™re overhauling Stack Overflowâ€™s email subscription UX.

The Current State of Email Preference Centers

When I hear folks talk about email, usually it goes something likeÂ this:

Want to receive unwanted emails for the rest of your life, and possibly the life of your children? Stay at a hotel ONCE.

 — @flcarneiro

â€¦or thisâ€¦

What they don't tell you about college is HOW MANY UNSOLICITED EMAIL NEWSLETTERS YOUR SCHOOL SENDS YOU EVERY DAY!!!!!!

 — @brennateefy

â€¦or this:

There's a special place in hell for services that require log in to unsubscribe from their newsletter.

 — @SaraSoueidan

I canâ€™t blame them; why trust anyone when there are so many bad actors out there? Sometimes it seems like you mysteriously get on an email list and have to jump through hoops to getÂ off.

Until about a year ago, Stack Overflow didnâ€™t send much email aside from a few messages sent to active Q&A users and basic things like resetting a password. Weâ€™ve been working hard to ramp up Stack Overflowâ€™s email program and send better targeted emails. As our email program evolved, we knew our email preferences needed to keep pace. Our existing design wasnâ€™t going to cut it, so we set out to redesign Stack Overflowâ€™s email preference center.

Our Goal

First, we needed to fix our legacy system in order to avoid becoming the bad actor ourselves. Designing for a community that connects over 50 million developers can pose some unique challenges. We created a few design principles to help guide our ideas for Stack Overflowâ€™s email preference center:

  1. Be honest about whatâ€™s happening.
  2. Be clear about whatâ€™s possible.
  3. Be quick in removing roadblocks and honoring usersâ€™Â wishes.

Common Pitfalls (and what we did to solveÂ them)

Pitfall #1: Inundating folks with emails afterÂ signup

How many times have you joined a new service and gotten opted into EVERY SINGLE EMAIL THEY SEND? Yeah, we didnâ€™t want to be that guyâ€¦ but at the same time, we were underselling ourselves by playing it too conservative with email. Users frequently made comments like â€œOh I didnâ€™t know you had x/y/z feature.â€ Rather than just not send any email at all, we had to convince ourselves that we could do it in a responsible way.

One of my biggest apprehensions is annoying our community. Worrying about that keeps me up at night.â€Šâ€”â€ŠNickÂ Craver

We reorganized our email categories and reconsidered how folks are opted into each one. We made email subscriptions trigger-based wherever possible. For example, we donâ€™t send you any Jobs emails until you engage with the Jobs product (apply for a job, set status to â€˜lookingâ€™, etc.). We donâ€™t send you any community emails until youâ€™ve participated. We donâ€™t opt you into any newsletters. And no, we donâ€™t employ any pop-ups imploring you (or shaming you) to sign up. We donâ€™t even have an email signup form on mostÂ pages.

And when we do email you, we tell you why. Every email includes a reason you got email. We watched our language and made sure our internal speak didnâ€™t end up in the text (such as â€œProfile merge expired,â€ â€œActive status decayed,â€ and other glorious names we give emails at Stack Overflow).

Lastly, we do our best to remove folks who probably donâ€™t want to be emailed. If an email is rejected, weâ€™ll unsubscribe you. If youâ€™re unresponsive to emails we send, weâ€™ll unsubscribe you. If you mark it as spam, weâ€™ll unsubscribe you. We want to keep in touch, but only in ways that you findÂ helpful.

TAKEAWAY:
Be honest: Weâ€™re careful about not emailing anyone who doesnâ€™t want to hear from us. If weâ€™re not sure, we donâ€™t send theÂ email.

Pitfall #2: Sending poorly targetedÂ emails

So many times, I sign up for a service and get an email I didnâ€™tÂ expect.

â€œWhere did this comeÂ from?â€
â€œWhat did I do to receiveÂ this?â€
â€œHow do I change my preferences?â€

When a preference center gives me a lot of options, I want to know what exactly each of those options actually means. A list of vague categories like â€œAnnouncementsâ€ or â€œProduct Updatesâ€ doesnâ€™t set clear expectations about what email Iâ€™d receive and how often Iâ€™d receiveÂ them.

Same goes for when I receive an email. So many times, Iâ€™ve arrived at a preferences page after clicking â€œunsubscribeâ€ in an email and have no idea which email I just turned off. Itâ€™s often hard to tell exactly what category controls a certain email, so I have to guess and disable certain message types until I stop getting the ones I donâ€™t want anyÂ more.

We addressed this by including a brief explanation of each email category. Where possible, we say how often we send an email. We try to be as clear as possible so a user may edit their preferences with confidence.

If the unsubscribe link is clicked in any email, we bring you to your email preferences with that email highlighted so itâ€™s clear what you just unsubscribed from. Regardless of how you end up in your email preferences, we want your experience to be as good as possible.

Stack Overflow highlights the email you unsubscribed from so you donâ€™t have toÂ guess.

TAKEAWAY:
Be clear: We describe each email and highlight important actions so users know whatâ€™s goingÂ on.

Pitfall #3: Poor, Inaccessible EmailÂ UX

When updating your email preferences, how many times have you been forcedÂ toâ€¦

  • â€¦log into a site orÂ app?
  • â€¦navigate a non-responsive site onÂ mobile?
  • â€¦make sense of confusing text?
  • â€¦type your email address (onÂ mobile)?
  • â€¦confirm an unsubscribe?
  • â€¦wait a week for it toÂ process?
There is nothing worse than making the user do more than completely necessary when it comes to trying to remove themselves from communications.- Becs Rivett-Kemm

We think of this as any other conversion. If we optimize the landing pages from our emails, why not our subscription preferences? Unsubscribing might not be a flow we want them to complete, but if thatâ€™s what someone wants to do we shouldnâ€™t make it any harder than it has toÂ be.

We provide a one-click unsubscribe wherever we can. We did a lot of discovery and prototyping on when to include an unsubscribe link in email footers; itâ€™s not always clear! For instance, we researched the Welcome Email for 15 websites and found only about half included an unsubscribe link.

You can edit most of your Stack Overflow emails on a phone, without logging in, with a single click or tap. Changes are instant. And no, we donâ€™t send an unsubscribe confirmation email.

TAKEAWAY:
Be quick: We removed every roadblock weÂ could.

Conclusion

Good subscription UX takes care of youâ€Šâ€”â€Šyour privacy and the quality of your email life. It makes sensible decisions for you that respect your time, data, and attention. We provide sensible defaults, but give you choice, independence, and power to make your own experience.

  • Be honest about whatâ€™s happening, why, and what you can do about it. Designs should build confidence through transparency.
  • Be clear about whatâ€™s possible. Everything we make should be as understandable, descriptive, and inclusive.
  • Be quick in removing roadblocks and honoring usersâ€™ wishes. Designs should remove contextual barriers and meet them wherever they are. Accessible design is goodÂ design.

This article shows how we applied our design principles to the design of Stack Overflowâ€™s email preference center. Donna Choi wrote about how we designed the UX behind unified email management for Stack Overflowâ€™s 150+ siteÂ network.

Thanks to Donna and Kristina for their help with this article.

item.title: Anyone Can Open Source!
item.dc:creator: Ted Goas
item.content:encoded:
Lessons learned from creating and maintaining a modestly successful open sourceÂ project.

This article is adapted from a talk I gave at the Stack Overflow Design Meetup In JulyÂ 2017.

Before we start, a few quickÂ bits:

  1. You donâ€™t need to know how to code to do openÂ source.
  2. Open source doesnâ€™t have to require a lot ofÂ time.
  3. This article is focused on maintaining your own project. Contributing to othersâ€™ projects is also important, but I wonâ€™t cover thatÂ here.
  4. Open source projects can lead to pleasant surprises. Iâ€™ve used mine as leverage to get pay raises and at least one speakingÂ gig.

Iâ€™m a designer. In 2013 I created Cerberus, a set of simple HTML email templates that solve a lot of common gotchas in getting emails to display properly across email clients. I have a few open source projects, but Cerberus is my main jam. Itâ€™s been used by the team at dribbble, and is included in products like Dreamweaver and LitmusÂ Builder.

In this article, Iâ€™d like to share a few tips that guide my open source work and show a few examples of some awesome open source projects.

1. Choose Something Timeless and Stick WithÂ It

Thereâ€™s a saying that certain jobs are recession-proof. Iâ€™m not suggesting every open source project should survive the nuclear apocalypse, but there are certainly parallels. A project should be something that can evolve through paradigm shifts. Something trendy like a long-shadow generator is probably not a good bet, but so many projects end up needing a good tooltip at someÂ point.

For me, email is an obvious choice. Email is mature, ubiquitous, and has proven staying powerâ€¦ no matter how many people proclaim that email is dead. When I started Cerberus, I worked on it slowly and steadily for a few years before anyone started noticing it. And thatâ€™s ok, because emailâ€™s gonna be around for aÂ while.

2. Make It Small andÂ Focused

I have a full-time job, a young family, own a house, and enjoy life away from screens. I mostly work on my project alone, so itâ€™s important not to spread myself too thin. I resist building bells and whistles; theyâ€™re more to maintain. I minimize dependencies; theyâ€™re roadblocks for folks getting started. Iâ€™ve left the design open for folks to adapt it for their ownÂ needs.

Cerberus is a few simple, but solid patterns for responsive HTMLÂ emails.

Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s on the tin. Cerberusâ€™s design is grayscale, uses placeholder images, and contains dummy text. It doesnâ€™t even define a font. Itâ€™s intentionally simple and unassuming. It does just a few things but it does them really well. Well, thatâ€™s the goalÂ anyway.

When considering new features, I think about 37Signalsâ€™s â€œStart with Noâ€ in Getting Real. A while back, I was asked to extend Cerberusâ€™s three-column layout to support fourÂ columns.

GitHub-User: Hi, can you please make a four columnÂ layout?
Me: Hmm, thatâ€™s possible. Can you tell me a little about what you need itÂ for?
â€¦

I got no response. Building a four column layout was totally possible, but I never built it because it wasnâ€™t important enough to this person. No oneâ€™s asked for itÂ since.

Itâ€™s like Fight Club. You should only consider features if theyâ€™re willing to stand on the porch for three days waiting to be letÂ in.

3. DogfoodÂ It

This might go without saying, but using my own project helps me understand how it can be used so common workflows can be optimized. Email has been part of nearly every project Iâ€™ve worked on in the past few years, so I reach for Cerberus quiteÂ often.

Dogfooding itÂ helpsâ€¦

  • find and fix bugs in darkÂ corners
  • write documentation
  • educate and offer tips on how best to adapt and extend theÂ project

4. Work on Non-Visible Features

I designed for a healthcare company for six years. Our work was heavily regulated (HIPAA) and we had strict privacy and security protocols. Every so often, Iâ€™d search for a plugin or tool to solve a problem. I usually found something that did the trick, but it would violate U.S. healthcare regulations.

Well $@*#â€¦ canâ€™t use thisÂ one!

I had a lot of these moments. It was very frustrating.

But it made me appreciate things like accessibility, download speed, industry-specific compliance (higher education, healthcare, government, etc.), and browser / device support. I donâ€™t want to knowingly exclude folks from being able to use myÂ project.

The world doesn't need new and innovative interaction patterns as much as designers believe. It just needs shit to work.

 — @gem_ray

5. Double-Down on Documentation

As amazingly self-documenting as I think my project isâ€¦ yea, itâ€™s really not. Prioritizing documentation makes a project more approachable and understandable. I try to remind myself that no one is in my brain but me (I hope). All those decisions I made in my head may as well not even exist to anyone else unless theyâ€™re documented somewhere.

  • A decent readme helps people get up andÂ running.
  • Documentation helps explain why things work the way theyÂ do.
  • Code comments are good for for granularÂ things.
  • Good commit messages explain what changed, when, andÂ why.
  • Thoughtful discussions in GitHub issues and pull requests explain what ideas were considered and why they were implemented (or not implemented).
  • Demos help visualize results.

6. Include Instructions on How to Contribute

As my project matured, it started to get a little attention. As folks started using it, they had ideas on how to fix stuff or add to the project. This is a great thing, though I hit a few stumbling blocks in the beginning because I didnâ€™t specify any contribution guidelines. So Iâ€™d occasionally get messages likeÂ this:

GitHub-User: Hey, I found and fixed a bug in a template. Hereâ€™s a pullÂ request!
Me: Thank you very much! Hey, Cerberus is actually three templates, would you mind fixing the otherÂ two?

People didnâ€™t know how to help because I didnâ€™t tell them. face-palm-dot-gif

I created some contribution guidelines in the projectâ€™s docs to help steer the project in the direction I wanted to see it go and direct help where itâ€™s needed most. So I donâ€™t get a pull request out of nowhere with some changes I donâ€™tÂ want.

Examples!!

Alright, enough advice. Here are a few simple, focused, and well-documented open source projects I keep coming backÂ to.

Bulletproof Background Images inÂ Email

Getting background images to display in email clients takes a lot of code that Iâ€™ll never memorize. This project provides a few options and spits out working code that can be pasted into any email template. It does this one thing reallyÂ well.

Open Color

This project researched a color palette optimized for interfaces. Itâ€™s been tested for things like accessibility, brightness, and contrast across a range of different screens. The whole project is colors. Thatâ€™s all it is. Brilliant.

.htaccess Snippets

I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™d ever edited anÂ .htaccess without bringing an entire site downâ€¦ until I found this project. The entire project is the readme.md file, which contains paste-able snippets of commonÂ .htaccess commands. Iâ€™ll reference this until the day we hire anÂ .htaccess programmer ğŸ˜†.

Contract Killer

Contract Killer is a popular open source contract for web professionals that translates confusing legal passages into laymanâ€™s terms. The entire project is a text document in a GitHub Gist. A contract is part of any freelance project I take on, so Iâ€™ve adapted my own version that I use eachÂ time.

Wrapping up

Iâ€™m so happy you made it this far! So, toÂ recap:

  • Choose something timeless.
  • Keep it small andÂ focused.
  • Use it yourself.
  • Invest in good documentation.
  • Guide folks on how to contribute.

Are you grinding on an open source project? Thinking about starting one? Iâ€™d love to know if you found something in here useful. Please leave a comment or ping me on Twitter. On the off-chance youâ€™ve used Cerberus in a project, Iâ€™d love to hear about it!Â âœŒï¸

We launched this update as part of a series of changes supporting our core mission: Make developersâ€™ lives better. In the past year, we fully integrated our by-developers, for-developers Jobs product. We added a whole new content typeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDocumentationâ€Šâ€”â€Što help you find even more solutions to your programming questions. And we added Developer Story to help developers ditch the outdated resumeÂ format.

During this time, we also evolved our product development process to include more user research, allowing us to validate ideas earlier and surface more usersâ€™ voices. Thereâ€™s a ton you can learn by watching people try to use a featureâ€Šâ€”â€Šthings that donâ€™t get uncovered when directly soliciting feedback. As both product and process expanded, it quickly became apparent that Stack Overflow had outgrown some of our previous design decisions.

A CommonÂ Theme

A pattern surfaced when talking to users: even with the addition of Jobs and Documentation to the navigation, many developers werenâ€™t aware of the change. Digging deeper, we discovered that many werenâ€™t really seeing the top bar at allâ€Šâ€”â€Ša â€œmental blockâ€ so effective that most users also couldnâ€™t identify what the iconsÂ meant.

Hereâ€™s what a few of youÂ said:

â€œI scroll down and read the question.â€

The data validated our hypothesisâ€Šâ€”â€Šof the average 9.3 million daily visits to Stack Overflow, we get fewer than 88,000 clicks to the navigation or top bar (this includes inbox, rep, profile, and search.) If you divided each individual click per visit, thatâ€™s fewer than 1% of visits navigating anywhere (and far fewer if you counted multiple clicks per visit). Our navigation is not being used by 99% of ourÂ users.

The common use case for millions of daily visitors is â€œcome from Google, scroll to middle of the page to a find an answer (without seeing the nav and sometimes evening ignore the question itself), and leave. This workflow makes senseâ€Šâ€”â€Šand we love helping the worldâ€™s developers gain programming knowledge quicklyâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut this also means many visitors donâ€™t benefit from everything that Stack Overflow has to offer. If theyâ€™re not aware, then weâ€™re less effective in helping more developers share their knowledge by finding questions to answer, advance their career search, utilize Documentation, or become contributing members of our community.

We hypothesized that a lack of engagement with the nav was due to a combination of browsing habits, visual hierarchy, and the right-hand position of the layout. Based on research about F-shaped reading patterns and how readersâ€™ eyes commonly move down the page, it made sense that our navigation was sub-optimal for mostÂ people.

We also hypothesized that the focal point of the page (the logo) caused many users to skip over the small top bar. Plus the nav and top bar quickly scroll out of view when moving down theÂ page.

The product design team then did a design sprint. Each designer created their own design of the top nav and then converged to critique and identify the strongest ideas.

The team then combined the best parts of their ideas into one design. The main thinking generated from theÂ sprint:

  • Remove clutter and group similar information in a way thatâ€™s more quicklyÂ parsable
  • Stick the navigation to the top of the page so that users who are scrolling quickly to answers or arriving from answer or comment links still have access to search or navigate theÂ site
  • Use navigation design patterns more commonly found in contemporary webÂ apps
  • Design the navigation as shorthand for the Stack OverflowÂ brand
â€œIâ€™m not even sure if the black bar isÂ new.â€
â€œI logically filter out the stuff that I know Iâ€™m not lookingÂ for.â€
â€œNav looks like tagsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey might filter, but they donâ€™t look like navigation. Makes you question what it is so I donâ€™t click it and instead go back to Google that Iâ€™m familiarÂ with.â€
â€œIâ€™m signed in and I still donâ€™t know what those (inbox, achievements) mean.â€
â€œJumbled stuff at the top that you have to read and decipher.â€
â€œBlack bar is kindaâ€¦ doesnâ€™t look like it belongs, all else is white, grey,Â orange.â€

And the newÂ version:

â€œOn the current nav I didnâ€™t know what the inbox / rep icons were, on the new one I know what every button willÂ do.â€
â€œI know I can search, I know I can go toÂ Jobs.â€
â€œMuch more modern, thisÂ one.â€
â€œI like the old black bar, but I like that I know what Iâ€™m getting myself into on the newÂ one.â€
â€œA lot less noise, moreÂ signal.â€

â€œMore standardized position that youâ€™re used to on otherÂ sites.â€

Project Definition

At this point there was enough info to make the top navigation redesign an actual project. The nav is an area of the site that touches so many different use cases, user types, and metrics; it was important to tightly scope the project and clearly define the goals in advance in order to ship quickly. To mitigate scope creep, feature parity to the current navigation was the defined scope (with a few exceptions).

Primary goals

  • Present all the tools we provide for developers in a way thatâ€™s consistent with them actually discovering them
  • Increase traffic to Jobs and Documentation
  • More intuitive, updated visualÂ design
  • Increase the number of users who sign up and gain access to more siteÂ features

Secondary goals

  • Increase in notifications acknowledged
  • Increase or no decline inÂ searches
  • No decline in questions asked
  • And a handful of other important and boring metrics that we simply didnâ€™t want to screwÂ up

The progressive rollout plan to measure success had the following objectives:

  • Usability tests on clickable prototype with 6 additional users to catch any major UX and functionality issues and gather qualitative insights about the newÂ design
  • A/B test with 5% of anonymous users to measure usageÂ data
  • A/B test with 10% of registered users with less than 500 reputation to measure usageÂ data
  • Opt-in for all Stack Overflow employees
  • Opt-in for all users for Meta feedback and for debugging

Our findings fromÂ eachâ€¦

Usability Tests

These tests were conducted in 1â€“1 recorded hangouts with 6 users who ranged from having low to high reputation.

While a few participants struggled with identifying two of the icons (which were updated mid-testing), all participants successfully completed all tasks, and all participants preferred the new design over theÂ current.

â€œLooks really, really good. By far I like the new oneâ€Šâ€”â€Šin the current one, you donâ€™t notice the navigation at all, only the top bar. The (sub) tabs catch my eye before the current navigation.â€
â€œIn the old, it is weird to me that the two bars exist separately. This one feels more natural.â€
â€œThe new one is cleaner. Less wasted space. Things are more compact on the new one and account info is better grouped. Tabs across the top is preferable because a lot of sites have a similar flow.Â â€¦much prefer the newÂ one.â€

A/B Test with 5% of Anonymous Visitors

This test ran from 2016â€“12â€“01 to 2017â€“01â€“19 for about 2 million users in each A/B group. Anonymous visitors account for about 97% of all page views but only 61% of the current navigation clicks.

  • Signups increased byÂ 7%
  • Clicks to Questions increased byÂ 163%
  • Clicks to Jobs increased byÂ 160%
  • Clicks to Documentation increased byÂ 229%
  • Clicks to Tags increased byÂ 113%
  • Clicks to Users increased byÂ 178%
  • Clicks to Ask Question increased byÂ 33%
  • Searches decreased byÂ 13%*

*Adjustments to the design between the anonymous test and the registered user test were made that resolved this issue and actually improved the number of searches in the nextÂ test.

While some dropoff often happens after launch due to novelty effect, these increases were large enough to make us think that a good portion of the increases would be sustained after launch. Regardless, weâ€™ll continue to measure and monitor the performance of the new topÂ nav.

A/B Test with 10% of Registered Users with Less than 500Â Rep

This test ran from 2017â€“01â€“18 to 2017â€“01â€“30 for about 100k users in each A/B groupÂ . Registered user account for about 3% of all page views but about 44% of the current top navigation clicks.

  • Inboxes shown increased byÂ 45%
  • Achievements shown increased byÂ 11%
  • Clicks to Questions increased byÂ 51%
  • Clicks to Jobs increased byÂ 99%
  • Clicks to Documentation increased byÂ 113%
  • Clicks to Tags increased byÂ 32%
  • Clicks to Users increased byÂ 82%
  • Clicks to Ask Question remained theÂ same
  • Searches increased byÂ 8%

Opt-in for Stack Overflow Employees

This phase began Tuesday, February 1. About 100 Stack Overflow employees opted in to test the new topÂ nav.

Opt-in for AllÂ Users

This phase began 2017â€“02â€“07 to 2017â€“02â€“14. Around 1600 users optedÂ in.

Feedback from the Meta community has been extremely helpful. Thank you to everyone who participated! A number of bugs were fixed during this period, some feature requests were implemented and others considered orÂ planned.

Next Steps

Thereâ€™s a running list of ideas weâ€™d like to try in the near future. We plan on iterating upon the design and functionality of our new top nav in a series of A/B tests. There are also early-phase explorations into how this might roll out to international and other Stack Exchange community sites.

The design team is working on a cohesive design language in order to create consistent experiences across all our product areas. Some of these changes have already rolled out, and more are coming in the near future. Special thanks to PaweÅ‚ Ludwiczakâ€™s and Oded Costerâ€™s hard work designing and implementing the new top navigation.

As always, we appreciate your feedback. If you have a bug or feature requestâ€Šâ€”â€Špost it onÂ Meta.
